Day 1

Bachelor & Executor

1.Executor: Halt! I'm going to have to teach you about the technicalities of the setting. The time and the place. It's non-essential, but that's just how it is-the actor has to be prepared before he goes onstage, or else he'll fall down the aisle or stumble upon the prompt box. That would look mighty silly, wouldn't you agree?

1.Executor: Halt! I'm going to have to teach you about the technicalities of the setting. The time and the place. It's non-essential, but that's just how it is-the actor has to be prepared before he goes onstage, or else he'll fall down the aisle or stumble upon the prompt box. That would look mighty silly, wouldn't you agree?

2.Bachelor: Speak. I'm listening.

2.Bachelor: Speak. I'm listening.

3.Executor: Time flies by. It can't be stopped or turned back. Nights follow days, which are then followed by nights. Things happen without any regard for whether you're there to witness them. Don't expect anyone to wait for you. Most events can be missed.

3.Executor: Time flies by. It can't be stopped or turned back. Nights follow days, which are then followed by nights. Things happen without any regard for whether you're there to witness them. Don't expect anyone to wait for you. Most events can be missed.

4.Bachelor: And so?

4.Bachelor: And so?

5.Executor: And so it would make sense for you to visit the places that you care about regularly. You'll find the people that will play major roles in your fate there. They stand out from the common folk; the rest are just a crowd shot, a background, a bunch of extras.

5.Executor: And so it would make sense for you to visit the places that you care about regularly. You'll find the people that will play major roles in your fate there. They stand out from the common folk; the rest are just a crowd shot, a background, a bunch of extras.

6.Bachelor: As it has always been.

6.Bachelor: As it has always been.

7.Executor: Indeed. Still, it's best to avoid hasty judgement. It's a paradox, you see: don't try to care too much for the lives of these... bound-to-stand-out people. And don't be too dismissive of the silent crowd. Both extremes will end in tragedy.

7.Executor: Indeed. Still, it's best to avoid hasty judgement. It's a paradox, you see: don't try to care too much for the lives of these... bound-to-stand-out people. And don't be too dismissive of the silent crowd. Both extremes will end in tragedy.

8.Bachelor: Why is that?

8.Bachelor: Why is that?

9.Executor: This world cares for your reputation. A fine and crucial instrument. Your reputation changes the world you see-for it is a mirror, wouldn't you agree? And so a bad reputation can get you into a lot of trouble...

9.Executor: This world cares for your reputation. A fine and crucial instrument. Your reputation changes the world you see-for it is a mirror, wouldn't you agree? And so a bad reputation can get you into a lot of trouble...

10.Bachelor: For example?

10.Bachelor: For example?

11.Executor: Oh, need I describe? You've got vivid imagination... Everything changes, from mystical aspects to mundane things like the people you need treating you badly. How many enemies you've got... How high the prices rise... How bad your dreams are... Lots of things.

11.Executor: Oh, need I describe? You've got vivid imagination... Everything changes, from mystical aspects to mundane things like the people you need treating you badly. How many enemies you've got... How high the prices rise... How bad your dreams are... Lots of things.

12.Bachelor: A sorry prospect. So how do I maintain my reputation?

12.Bachelor: A sorry prospect. So how do I maintain my reputation?

13.Executor: Really...? How is that even a question? Same as anywhere! Thou shalt not kill. Thou shalt not lie. Thou shalt not betray. Do not steal... Do not covet... Do not be an asshole. Do not get caught... The rules are the same everywhere. A truly selfless deed-like risking something for thy neighbour or even a person who lives quite far away-can help in a dire situation.

13.Executor: Really...? How is that even a question? Same as anywhere! Thou shalt not kill. Thou shalt not lie. Thou shalt not betray. Do not steal... Do not covet... Do not be an asshole. Do not get caught... The rules are the same everywhere. A truly selfless deed-like risking something for thy neighbour or even a person who lives quite far away-can help in a dire situation.

14.Bachelor: I see.

14.Bachelor: I see.

15.Executor: Really? Good for you then. As for me, I can't see anything in this mask. I have no idea what's going on. Anyway, don't get too worked up about human lives. And don't put too much stock into another's words, mine included... He who trusts everyone is asking to be deceived.

15.Executor: Really? Good for you then. As for me, I can't see anything in this mask. I have no idea what's going on. Anyway, don't get too worked up about human lives. And don't put too much stock into another's words, mine included... He who trusts everyone is asking to be deceived.

16.Bachelor: Definitely.

16.Bachelor: Definitely.

16.Bachelor: Yet he who trusts no one is deluded. I know that from experience.

16.Bachelor: Yet he who trusts no one is deluded. I know that from experience.

16.Bachelor: Speaking of trust, where does Simon Kain reside? I would be most thankful if you showed me the way.

16.Bachelor: Speaking of trust, where does Simon Kain reside? I would be most thankful if you showed me the way.

17.Executor: Simon Kain does not 'reside', he lives, or rather exists! He reigns, he creates, he makes mistakes and brings joy to the people with the mere fact of his existence. All that happens at the Crucible. Go left along this alley. As you reach Bridge Square, look to the right. You'll see it.

17.Executor: Simon Kain does not 'reside', he lives, or rather exists! He reigns, he creates, he makes mistakes and brings joy to the people with the mere fact of his existence. All that happens at the Crucible. Go left along this alley. As you reach Bridge Square, look to the right. You'll see it.

18.Bachelor: Thank you.

18.Bachelor: Thank you.

2.Bachelor: Who are you?

2.Bachelor: Who are you?

3.Executor: An actor in a tragic mime show. That's unimportant. Will you listen to me or not?

3.Executor: An actor in a tragic mime show. That's unimportant. Will you listen to me or not?

4.Bachelor: I am listening.

4.Bachelor: I am listening.

5.Executor: Time flies by. It can't be stopped or turned back. Nights follow days, which are then followed by nights. Things happen without any regard for whether you're there to witness them. Don't expect anyone to wait for you. Most events can be missed.

6.Bachelor: And so?

10.Bachelor: Why is that?

12.Bachelor: For example?

2.Bachelor: You're 'going to have to teach me'? Aren't you forgetting your manners?

2.Bachelor: You're 'going to have to teach me'? Aren't you forgetting your manners?

3.Executor: My manners? There are different manners of life and thought, none of them mine. If everything goes awry, you'll get a chance to witness each of them; that is something you should probably try to avoid. As for now, please forgive my rudeness. I'm in a special position here, and so I have the right to be blunt sometimes.

3.Executor: My manners? There are different manners of life and thought, none of them mine. If everything goes awry, you'll get a chance to witness each of them; that is something you should probably try to avoid. As for now, please forgive my rudeness. I'm in a special position here, and so I have the right to be blunt sometimes.

Bachelor & Tragedian

1.Tragedian: Venerable Bachelor? Please be so kind as to linger for a minute. This conversation won't take too much of your time, especially since time stops during dialogues... at least during the important ones. And our dialogue is extremely important! You need to know how to play after all, don't you?

1.Tragedian: Venerable Bachelor? Please be so kind as to linger for a minute. This conversation won't take too much of your time, especially since time stops during dialogues... at least during the important ones. And our dialogue is extremely important! You need to know how to play after all, don't you?

2.Bachelor: Play? What are you talking about, Mask Man? I'm neither a gambler nor an actor.

2.Bachelor: Play? What are you talking about, Mask Man? I'm neither a gambler nor an actor.

3.Tragedian: Of course you aren't! You are a living breathing man-as is evident from your conditions and statuses. You experience hunger, thirst, and fatigue; you suffer from pain, wounds, and diseases. You're so lifelike! You have to eat, drink, sleep, and rest. And to make mistakes...

3.Tragedian: Of course you aren't! You are a living breathing man-as is evident from your conditions and statuses. You experience hunger, thirst, and fatigue; you suffer from pain, wounds, and diseases. You're so lifelike! You have to eat, drink, sleep, and rest. And to make mistakes...

4.Bachelor: The latter being the most definitive proof of my human nature, wouldn't you agree?

4.Bachelor: The latter being the most definitive proof of my human nature, wouldn't you agree?

5.Tragedian: If I may, I would like to point out just how important it is to keep an eye on your condition. If you get dizzy or unnaturally sluggish, do have it checked up... Vital processes tend to run faster during emergencies than in everyday life. I knew a person who died of stress but was diagnosed with starvation...

5.Tragedian: If I may, I would like to point out just how important it is to keep an eye on your condition. If you get dizzy or unnaturally sluggish, do have it checked up... Vital processes tend to run faster during emergencies than in everyday life. I knew a person who died of stress but was diagnosed with starvation...

6.Bachelor: It happens. I can testify to that as a doctor.

6.Bachelor: It happens. I can testify to that as a doctor.

7.Tragedian: Need I remind a wise man like you of the fact that hunger is sated with food? Food can be found in shops, and shops can be found in ordinary houses that are marked with specific signs. Sleep, however, is more complicated. People only sleep in beds and only in private residences around here. I am sorry, but that's just how our world is...

7.Tragedian: Need I remind a wise man like you of the fact that hunger is sated with food? Food can be found in shops, and shops can be found in ordinary houses that are marked with specific signs. Sleep, however, is more complicated. People only sleep in beds and only in private residences around here. I am sorry, but that's just how our world is...

8.Bachelor: Yes, the world is unjust.

8.Bachelor: Yes, the world is unjust.

9.Tragedian: And quite silly, if you forgive me for saying so... Speaking of commerce, different shops sell similar items at different prices. Make sure you don't get cheated... people can be quite brazen around here! You can also barter with the folk out in the street. Some things may be nothing more than trinkets to you, but others would be willing to part with their life's blood for them...

9.Tragedian: And quite silly, if you forgive me for saying so... Speaking of commerce, different shops sell similar items at different prices. Make sure you don't get cheated... people can be quite brazen around here! You can also barter with the folk out in the street. Some things may be nothing more than trinkets to you, but others would be willing to part with their life's blood for them...

10.Bachelor: Blood?

10.Bachelor: Blood?

11.Tragedian: Yes, blood... It's not my place to lecture you, but if-following your Hippocratic oath-you ever consider easing someone's pain, feel free to just approach them with a suitable drug. You will see their pain receding before your very eyes. The sick fall asleep when they're close to recovery, don't they?

11.Tragedian: Yes, blood... It's not my place to lecture you, but if-following your Hippocratic oath-you ever consider easing someone's pain, feel free to just approach them with a suitable drug. You will see their pain receding before your very eyes. The sick fall asleep when they're close to recovery, don't they?

12.Bachelor: Or when they're close to their ultimate rest.

12.Bachelor: Or when they're close to their ultimate rest.

13.Tragedian: Still, helping the hopeless will grant you a good reputation. You will be seen as a benefactor willing to part with a precious sleeping draught or a painkiller for a simple bystander.

13.Tragedian: Still, helping the hopeless will grant you a good reputation. You will be seen as a benefactor willing to part with a precious sleeping draught or a painkiller for a simple bystander.

14.Bachelor: Anything else?

14.Bachelor: Anything else?

15.Tragedian: No... No. Not yet.

15.Tragedian: No... No. Not yet.

16.Bachelor: Show me the way to Simon's house.

16.Bachelor: Show me the way to Simon's house.

17.Tragedian: Turn left now. Then walk along the alley; you will see a Cathedral and three mansions across Bridge Square; Simon lives in the one that is the closest to the river.

17.Tragedian: Turn left now. Then walk along the alley; you will see a Cathedral and three mansions across Bridge Square; Simon lives in the one that is the closest to the river.

18.Bachelor: Thank you.

18.Bachelor: Thank you.

16.Bachelor: Bye then, Mask.

16.Bachelor: Bye then, Mask.

10.Bachelor: You're a bore, mate. Let me through.

10.Bachelor: You're a bore, mate. Let me through.

6.Bachelor: Cut with the silliness, good sir. I can take care of myself.

6.Bachelor: Cut with the silliness, good sir. I can take care of myself.

4.Bachelor: No, I don't. Not me.

4.Bachelor: No, I don't. Not me.

5.Tragedian: If I may, I would like to point out just how important it is to keep an eye on your condition. If you get dizzy or unnaturally sluggish, do have it checked up... Vital processes tend to run faster during emergencies than in everyday life. I knew a person who died of stress but was diagnosed with starvation...

5.Tragedian: If I may, I would like to point out just how important it is to keep an eye on your condition. If you get dizzy or unnaturally sluggish, do have it checked up... Vital processes tend to run faster during emergencies than in everyday life. I knew a person who died of stress but was diagnosed with starvation...

6.Bachelor: It happens. I can testify to that as a doctor.

6.Bachelor: It happens. I can testify to that as a doctor.

7.Tragedian: Need I remind a wise man like you of the fact that hunger is sated with food? Food can be found in shops, and shops can be found in ordinary houses that are marked with specific signs. Sleep, however, is more complicated. People only sleep in beds and only in private residences around here. I am sorry, but that's just how our world is...

7.Tragedian: Need I remind a wise man like you of the fact that hunger is sated with food? Food can be found in shops, and shops can be found in ordinary houses that are marked with specific signs. Sleep, however, is more complicated. People only sleep in beds and only in private residences around here. I am sorry, but that's just how our world is...

8.Bachelor: Yes, the world is unjust.

8.Bachelor: Yes, the world is unjust.

9.Tragedian: And quite silly, if you forgive me for saying so... Speaking of commerce, different shops sell similar items at different prices. Make sure you don't get cheated... people can be quite brazen around here! You can also barter with the folk out in the street. Some things may be nothing more than trinkets to you, but others would be willing to part with their life's blood for them...

10.Bachelor: Blood?

10.Bachelor: Blood?

11.Tragedian: Yes, blood... It's not my place to lecture you, but if-following your Hippocratic oath-you ever consider easing someone's pain, feel free to just approach them with a suitable drug. You will see their pain receding before your very eyes. The sick fall asleep when they're close to recovery, don't they?

11.Tragedian: Yes, blood... It's not my place to lecture you, but if-following your Hippocratic oath-you ever consider easing someone's pain, feel free to just approach them with a suitable drug. You will see their pain receding before your very eyes. The sick fall asleep when they're close to recovery, don't they?

12.Bachelor: Or when they're close to their ultimate rest.

12.Bachelor: Or when they're close to their ultimate rest.

13.Tragedian: Still, helping the hopeless will grant you a good reputation. You will be seen as a benefactor willing to part with a precious sleeping draught or a painkiller for a simple bystander.

13.Tragedian: Still, helping the hopeless will grant you a good reputation. You will be seen as a benefactor willing to part with a precious sleeping draught or a painkiller for a simple bystander.

14.Bachelor: Anything else?

15.Tragedian: No... No. Not yet.

16.Bachelor: Show me the way to Simon's house.

16.Bachelor: Show me the way to Simon's house.

17.Tragedian: Turn left now. Then walk along the alley; you will see a Cathedral and three mansions across Bridge Square; Simon lives in the one that is the closest to the river.

17.Tragedian: Turn left now. Then walk along the alley; you will see a Cathedral and three mansions across Bridge Square; Simon lives in the one that is the closest to the river.

4.Bachelor: You are mistaken. I am the director. The person in charge of the situation. I'm not a random actor.

4.Bachelor: You are mistaken. I am the director. The person in charge of the situation. I'm not a random actor.

5.Tragedian: Of course you aren't! You are a living breathing man-as is evident from your conditions and statuses. You experience hunger, thirst, and fatigue; you suffer from pain, wounds, and diseases. You're so lifelike! You have to eat, drink, sleep, and rest. And to make mistakes...

Vital processes tend to run faster during emergencies than in everyday life. I knew a person who died of stress but was diagnosed with starvation...

Bachelor & Worm

1.Worm: The Worm feels sick... Head packed. Blood boiling. Belly freezing. Let the Worm warm up, let him take a rest... Don't touch us, we're dangerous!

1.Worm: The Worm feels sick... Head packed. Blood boiling. Belly freezing. Let the Worm warm up, let him take a rest... Don't touch us, we're dangerous!

2.Bachelor: Get lost. I'm even more dangerous.

2.Bachelor: Get lost. I'm even more dangerous.

2.Bachelor: Whoa, that's some stench, you animal... How on earth do you even live like that...

Bachelor & Factory Worker

1.Factory Worker: Whaddya want...? This ain't your business!

1.Factory Worker: Whaddya want...? This ain't your business!

2.Bachelor: What is this creature?

2.Bachelor: What is this creature?

3.Factory Worker: An odongh, duh! That's what all them cattle-breeders look like, crude and unshapely and unfinished. Dontcha know? Wherever you came from? An intruder, huh?

3.Factory Worker: An odongh, duh! That's what all them cattle-breeders look like, crude and unshapely and unfinished. Dontcha know? Wherever you came from? An intruder, huh?

4.Bachelor: It's you who are intruding. Go away.

4.Bachelor: It's you who are intruding. Go away.

5.Factory Worker: Dontcha see he's sick? He's a runaway, this odongh. Hide him all night long, I did, will march across the river now. Or else here he dies. Give him a break, will ya, he ain't gonna bite your head off. Be on your way! And watch out, too, we don't need no witnesses. Can do some killing if we must!

6.Bachelor: I'll show you 'some killing', you savage!

6.Bachelor: I'll show you 'some killing', you savage!

6.Bachelor: Fine, I'm leaving. Relax, I won't tell anyone about you.

Bachelor & Executor

1.Executor: The town is small and rather unexceptional, isn't it? But there are all kinds of people here. The simple folk-and the more remarkable ones. The former will tell you more than they know. The latter know way more than they're ever going to let out. Keep a close eye on them. Your victory depends on it.

1.Executor: The town is small and rather unexceptional, isn't it? But there are all kinds of people here. The simple folk-and the more remarkable ones. The former will tell you more than they know. The latter know way more than they're ever going to let out. Keep a close eye on them. Your victory depends on it.

2.Bachelor: And who are these remarkable people?

2.Bachelor: And who are these remarkable people?

3.Executor: There are twenty-something of them. Easily distinguished... by their lodgings or their presence. They're called many names: The Bound, The Fated, The Adherents, 'The Gobo's Taglur', The Town's Circle. Simon preferred their company to any other.

3.Executor: There are twenty-something of them. Easily distinguished... by their lodgings or their presence. They're called many names: The Bound, The Fated, The Adherents, 'The Gobo's Taglur', The Town's Circle. Simon preferred their company to any other.

4.Bachelor: Why?

4.Bachelor: Why?

5.Executor: Because it is they that will decide the fate of this town. Don't be distracted by the fact that some of them look insignificant or disreputable. They will earn their worth, you just give them time. They're the most important joints of the town.

5.Executor: Because it is they that will decide the fate of this town. Don't be distracted by the fact that some of them look insignificant or disreputable. They will earn their worth, you just give them time. They're the most important joints of the town.

6.Bachelor: Why are you telling me all this?

6.Bachelor: Why are you telling me all this?

7.Executor: Each day one of them will try death by the tooth. Each will put their life at risk. And each one that dies is important. Some of them may take the keys to victory to the grave... mind that the keys are yours, while the grave is theirs. Others will do the opposite. Don't waste your chance to condemn someone who may get in your way.

7.Executor: Each day one of them will try death by the tooth. Each will put their life at risk. And each one that dies is important. Some of them may take the keys to victory to the grave... mind that the keys are yours, while the grave is theirs. Others will do the opposite. Don't waste your chance to condemn someone who may get in your way.

8.Bachelor: How do you know what is helpful and what gets in the way?

8.Bachelor: How do you know what is helpful and what gets in the way?

9.Executor: Okay, okay, all right, dropping you more hints would be cheating... shutting up now. Allow me to conclude then. Each Bound you save will influence the finale of your... adventure. Each of them has their own goals and motives. It may so happen that those who seek a different ending survive, and then... well, you've been warned.

9.Executor: Okay, okay, all right, dropping you more hints would be cheating... shutting up now. Allow me to conclude then. Each Bound you save will influence the finale of your... adventure. Each of them has their own goals and motives. It may so happen that those who seek a different ending survive, and then... well, you've been warned.

10.Bachelor: Okay, I'll take that into account and will be careful.

10.Bachelor: Okay, I'll take that into account and will be careful.

10.Bachelor: I won't do a thing for anyone until I get to the bottom of what goes on here.

10.Bachelor: I won't do a thing for anyone until I get to the bottom of what goes on here.

4.Bachelor: Is that a sect or something?

4.Bachelor: Is that a sect or something?

5.Executor: No... There used to be a pagan game called 'taglur.' A roundelay of sorts. 'A taglur' means 'a kin circle', and Gobo is a character from a local epic. And so the people that Simon was intrested in the most are called the Gobo's Taglur. Some of them don't even know one another.

5.Executor: No... There used to be a pagan game called 'taglur.' A roundelay of sorts. 'A taglur' means 'a kin circle', and Gobo is a character from a local epic. And so the people that Simon was intrested in the most are called the Gobo's Taglur. Some of them don't even know one another.

6.Bachelor: How did Simon choose them?

Each of them has their own goals and motives. It may so happen that those who seek a different ending survive, and then... well, you've been warned.

16.Bachelor: Okay, I'll take that into account and will be careful.

16.Bachelor: Okay, I'll take that into account and will be careful.

16.Bachelor: I won't do a thing for anyone until I get to the bottom of what goes on here.

16.Bachelor: I won't do a thing for anyone until I get to the bottom of what goes on here.

Bachelor & Tragedian

1.Tragedian: There is something in particular we feel the urge to warn you about. When you speak to the Bound, please choose your words carefully. Do not worry, you will easily be able to make out what kind of a person is standing before you, an observant man that you are. So use that skill when dealing with the Bound; some of them are indeed worth insulting, whereas others need to be treated with utmost respect.

1.Tragedian: There is something in particular we feel the urge to warn you about. When you speak to the Bound, please choose your words carefully. Do not worry, you will easily be able to make out what kind of a person is standing before you, an observant man that you are. So use that skill when dealing with the Bound; some of them are indeed worth insulting, whereas others need to be treated with utmost respect.

2.Bachelor: I have no idea what you're talking about.

2.Bachelor: I have no idea what you're talking about.

3.Tragedian: Every line you utter will have consequences. News spreads rapidly around here. If you spoil your reputation in one place, you'll have to reap what you have sown in another. Restore your good name in the south, and you'll receive a warmer welcome in the north. They will heed every word you say-and you'll be rewarded.

3.Tragedian: Every line you utter will have consequences. News spreads rapidly around here. If you spoil your reputation in one place, you'll have to reap what you have sown in another. Restore your good name in the south, and you'll receive a warmer welcome in the north. They will heed every word you say-and you'll be rewarded.

4.Bachelor: Not by means of money, I hope?

4.Bachelor: Not by means of money, I hope?

5.Tragedian: A handful of money... It's not a dialogue fee, don't get me wrong! Never refuse to take small sums of money from the Bound. That would not belittle you in any fashion, but would rather demonstrate that you appreciate the local customs.

5.Tragedian: A handful of money... It's not a dialogue fee, don't get me wrong! Never refuse to take small sums of money from the Bound. That would not belittle you in any fashion, but would rather demonstrate that you appreciate the local customs.

6.Bachelor: All right, I'll keep local customs in mind.

6.Bachelor: How so?

6.Bachelor: How so?

7.Tragedian: It's a symbolic 'godspeed'. The heftier the sum, the better your luck is supposed to become. So conversations get more profitable as your reputation goes up, esteemed Bachelor.

7.Tragedian: It's a symbolic 'godspeed'. The heftier the sum, the better your luck is supposed to become. So conversations get more profitable as your reputation goes up, esteemed Bachelor.

8.Bachelor: I see.

8.Bachelor: I see.

Bachelor & Patrolman

1.Patrolman: A foul murder occurred here this night. No unauthorized access allowed. Inspecting the crime scene is strictly forbidden until further notice.

1.Patrolman: A foul murder occurred here this night. No unauthorized access allowed. Inspecting the crime scene is strictly forbidden until further notice.

2.Bachelor: Who was killed?

2.Bachelor: Who was killed?

3.Patrolman: Well, you're not a local, sir, so you're unlikely to understand the loss we've suffered... Isidor Burakh. A great surgeon, a benefactor to us all, and an all-around skilled doc. An outstanding man, beloved and well-respected by us locals. Does it really always have to take the very best...? What a foul time to live in...

3.Patrolman: Well, you're not a local, sir, so you're unlikely to understand the loss we've suffered... Isidor Burakh. A great surgeon, a benefactor to us all, and an all-around skilled doc. An outstanding man, beloved and well-respected by us locals. Does it really always have to take the very best...? What a foul time to live in...

4.Bachelor: I knew him. I'm a doctor too.

4.Bachelor: I knew him. I'm a doctor too.

5.Patrolman: Whoever killed our only doc must surely be looking to get us all killed. Isidor could cure anything; he also knew how to make cuts, or incisions, 'cause he was a warden. He knew his lines all right. Like I said, it all makes sense. Whoever killed Simon, took Isidor's life too. And this is merely the beginning...

5.Patrolman: Whoever killed our only doc must surely be looking to get us all killed. Isidor could cure anything; he also knew how to make cuts, or incisions, 'cause he was a warden. 6.Bachelor: What makes you think the two cases are connected?

6.Bachelor: What makes you think the two cases are connected?

7.Patrolman: Well, eh... Who would have the heart to attack such men? If you had asked me yesterday, I'd have told you no one would dare inflict such an ugly wound on this town. But if there is someone, it has to be just that: some ONE. Although it looks fishy, if you ask me... That thing was no man. That's what I think.

8.Bachelor: Explain yourself.

8.Bachelor: Explain yourself.

9.Patrolman: See, this murderous deal is all mysterious... There was a talon stuck in the victim's chest! Go ahead, bend your arm at the elbow, goodsir. Yeah, like that, there you go-that's how long it was. It broke off. There was dust on the floor, for the deceased had been a renowned Steppe-walker; and the dust was all covered in hoofsteps and, like, traces of a sharp bone, I guess? As if someone was using a walking stick 'round there. I'm telling you, it's her. The shabnak-adyr. The clay maneater.

10.Bachelor: I want to inspect the building.

11.Patrolman: We've been assigned to this post by Alexander, the head of the Saburov family. His house is in decline right now, but it's still powerful and very much respected-for it is they that's been responsible for maintaining wordly order and public safety in the town since olden days. Please kindly address your concerns to him. There's their Rod, you just take that road up there and get to the cape. As for me, I'm not authorized to let you in.

His house is in decline right now, but it's still powerful and very much respected-for it is they that's been responsible for maintaining wordly order and public safety in the town since olden days. Please kindly address your concerns to him. There's their Rod, you just take that road up there and get to the cape. As for me, I'm not authorized to let you in.

8.Bachelor: You should have said so from the start.

8.Bachelor: You should have said so from the start.

1.Patrolman: Look, this is no place for you to be, sir. Could you kindly leave? Eh? The place is villanous, and times are rough... what if some thug or cutthroat comes after you? I can't protect everyone...

1.Patrolman: Look, this is no place for you to be, sir. Could you kindly leave? Eh? The place is villanous, and times are rough... what if some thug or cutthroat comes after you? I can't protect everyone...

2.Bachelor: I'm doing my job. You do yours.

2.Bachelor: I'm doing my job. You do yours.

2.Bachelor: Don't get smart with me, soldier. I can hold my own.

2.Bachelor: Don't get smart with me, soldier. I can hold my own.

Bachelor & Hunchback

1.Hunchback: What d'ya need, kind sir?

1.Hunchback: What d'ya need, kind sir?

2.Bachelor: I'm looking for Grace. Where is she?

2.Bachelor: I'm looking for Grace. Where is she?

3.Hunchback: Ah, the caretaker's gal... No Grace 'round here, as you can see, the place is completely graceless. Heh heh... What's your business with her, eh?

3.Hunchback: Ah, the caretaker's gal... No Grace 'round here, as you can see, the place is completely graceless. Heh heh... What's your business with her, eh?

4.Bachelor: I need to bury a man without unnecessary fuss.

4.Bachelor: I need to bury a man without unnecessary fuss.

5.Hunchback: Aye, makes sense, loads o' sense. Hmm, hmm... Putting someone six feet under without any roaring thunder... The process demands meticulousness, kind sir, y'know that? How long since the stiff's gone stiff?

5.Hunchback: Aye, makes sense, loads o' sense. Hmm, hmm... Putting someone six feet under without any roaring thunder... The process demands meticulousness, kind sir, y'know that? How long since the stiff's gone stiff?

6.Bachelor: A bizarre question.

6.Bachelor: A bizarre question.

7.Hunchback: Ain't nothing bizarre 'bout that. If the goner's been gone for a long time, then there's just one concern for us, or maybe none at all... but if he died recently, ooh, if he died recently, we're in a completely different line of business here! Now, a person doesn't die just like that, now does he? The town's a-rumble and a-thunder, dontcha try sweet-talking me into believing he died his own death...

7.Hunchback: Ain't nothing bizarre 'bout that. If the goner's been gone for a long time, then there's just one concern for us, or maybe none at all... but if he died recently, ooh, if he died recently, we're in a completely different line of business here! Now, a person doesn't die just like that, now does he? The town's a-rumble and a-thunder, dontcha try sweet-talking me into believing he died his own death...

8.Bachelor: So you want money.

8.Bachelor: So you want money.

9.Hunchback: You bring two thousand here, kind sir, and we'll bury the devil himself and sing a pretty tune for you to boot. Gotta put even the shabnak-adyg back into the ground for two thousand. The sum ain't pretty, I know, but the times ain't killer on the looks either. I can show the kind sir a way out, by the way...

9.Hunchback: You bring two thousand here, kind sir, and we'll bury the devil himself and sing a pretty tune for you to boot. Gotta put even the shabnak-adyg back into the ground for two thousand. The sum ain't pretty, I know, but the times ain't killer on the looks either. I can show the kind sir a way out, by the way...

10.Bachelor: Well?

10.Bachelor: Well?

11.Hunchback: You're a big-city man, that I can feel a verst away. Your equipment would cost a fortune in our shops-the poor morons'd give you their souls for it, they buy all sorts of crap anyway. They've got loads of money saved up right now-what with the train coming soon and all. But them folks are addicted to not starving, so they're gradually selling their stuff. You could become a rich man in a few hours if you play your cards right.

Bachelor & Doghead

1.Doghead: May I inquire as to how you've found this place, sir?

1.Doghead: May I inquire as to how you've found this place, sir?

2.Bachelor: By accident. Why do you look so funny?

2.Bachelor: By accident. Why do you look so funny?

3.Doghead: We children are funny creatures: half human, half something else. Our inner world is off limits to the adults. You can't see our real faces just as you can't touch our dreams. Which is why we need these scary heads. See how it all works?

3.Doghead: We children are funny creatures: half human, half something else. Our inner world is off limits to the adults. You can't see our real faces just as you can't touch our dreams. Which is why we need these scary heads. See how it all works?

4.Bachelor: I see that you are here-and have no idea why that is.

4.Bachelor: I see that you are here-and have no idea why that is.

5.Doghead: Er... We're playing here. Rehearsing, actually... Also looking for something. We need it for the game. Nothing special, just some junk.

5.Doghead: Er... We're playing here. Rehearsing, actually... Also looking for something. We need it for the game. Nothing special, just some junk.

6.Bachelor: That doesn't sound too convincing. I am not a man to be trifled with, little scamp. I know everything.

6.Bachelor: That doesn't sound too convincing. I am not a man to be trifled with, little scamp. I know everything.

7.Doghead: ...Yeah, well, it can't be fixed now anyway! All right, I'll tell you. Who knows-perhaps you'll even be of help. The kids are in danger. We've come here to get shmowders, but someone has already looted the cache. Maybe it was Capella's doing? She's probably distributed them among her minions, the pagan!

7.Doghead: ...Yeah, well, it can't be fixed now anyway! All right, I'll tell you. Who knows-perhaps you'll even be of help. The kids are in danger. We've come here to get shmowders, but someone has already looted the cache. Maybe it was Capella's doing? She's probably distributed them among her minions, the pagan!

8.Bachelor: I don't understand a thing... How is it dangerous?

8.Bachelor: I don't understand a thing... How is it dangerous?

9.Doghead: The little ones are playing epidemic again. They wanted to get their hands on these damn shmowders so very much! So now we need to catch the kiddies-and I mean all the kiddies in the town, one by one-and pry the shmowders from their hands. See, the common opinion is that shmowders can cure all kinds of ailments and stuff, but in truth they're deadly!

9.Doghead: The little ones are playing epidemic again. They wanted to get their hands on these damn shmowders so very much! 10.Bachelor: Hmm... Why were they produced in the first place then?

11.Doghead: An adult will be severely poisoned-they'll be bedridden for a week or so... and that's it. But it spells doom for little kids!

11.Doghead: An adult will be severely poisoned-they'll be bedridden for a week or so... and that's it. But it spells doom for little kids!

12.Bachelor: How are children supposed to cure themselves then?

14.Bachelor: The Polyhedron?

15.Doghead: The Specular Tower on the other side of the river. There is no death, no grief, no boredom, and no disease there. That is proven for certain. Only dumbheads leave it voluntarily, if you ask me. You have to be an absolutely thick and heartless creature lacking any semblance of imagination to refuse something of the sort.

8.Bachelor: Capella? Tell me about her.

8.Bachelor: Capella? Tell me about her.

9.Doghead: Well.... Capella is Capella. Even though she's our foe, we still respect her. She's luring kids out of the tower, trying to organize a sect of some kind. And they worship her-like, for real. Well, that's understandable; she's the kind of girl that you could even fall in love with. Too bad she's not on our side! Of the river, that is. Pah, pride is the downfall of everyone.

9.Doghead: Well.... Capella is Capella. Even though she's our foe, we still respect her. She's luring kids out of the tower, trying to organize a sect of some kind. And they worship her-like, for real. Well, that's understandable; she's the kind of girl that you could even fall in love with. Too bad she's not on our side! Of the river, that is. 10.Bachelor: So what you're saying is she's distributed the shmowders among the kids, right?

10.Bachelor: So what you're saying is she's distributed the shmowders among the kids, right?

11.Doghead: The little ones are playing epidemic again. They wanted to get their hands on these damn shmowders so very much! So now we need to catch the kiddies-and I mean all the kiddies in the town, one by one-and pry the shmowders from their hands. See, the common opinion is that shmowders can cure all kinds of ailments and stuff, but in truth they're deadly!

And they worship her-like, for real. Well, that's understandable; she's the kind of girl that you could even fall in love with. Too bad she's not on our side! Of the river, that is. Pah, pride is the downfall of everyone.

See, the common opinion is that shmowders can cure all kinds of ailments and stuff, but in truth they're deadly!

14.Bachelor: All right, I get the general gist.

7.Doghead: Well.... Capella is Capella. Even though she's our foe, we still respect her. She's luring kids out of the tower, trying to organize a sect of some kind. And they worship her-like, for real. Well, that's understandable; she's the kind of girl that you could even fall in love with. Too bad she's not on our side! Of the river, that is. Pah, pride is the downfall of everyone.

See, the common opinion is that shmowders can cure all kinds of ailments and stuff, but in truth they're deadly!

Bachelor & Doghead

Day 2

1.Doghead: Oh man! Oh man! I told them to escape straight away without tossing a coin!

1.Doghead: Oh man! Oh man! I told them to escape straight away without tossing a coin!

2.Bachelor: Explain yourself.

2.Bachelor: Explain yourself.

3.Doghead: How are we supposed to find the shmowders now? Do we seriously need to detain every little kid in the street? What do we barter with them for? And we can't take the shmowders by force. Bullying is against the rules-Khan would totally bite our heads off for that.

3.Doghead: How are we supposed to find the shmowders now? Do we seriously need to detain every little kid in the street? What do we barter with them for? And we can't take the shmowders by force. Bullying is against the rules-Khan would totally bite our heads off for that.

4.Bachelor: 'Shmowders'? As in... 'powders'? What are you talking about?

4.Bachelor: 'Shmowders'? As in... 'powders'? What are you talking about?

5.Doghead: Oooh, powders! Powders-shmowders! Shmowders are sanative mixtures. They were invented during the First Outbreak. The original ones were made by Catchfly, but they were no good; the disease would pass, but the person would pass away along with it. But then Beaker's brothers made some nice ones. Crowfoot's weren't too shabby, and neither were Flanky's...

5.Doghead: Oooh, powders! Powders-shmowders! Shmowders are sanative mixtures. They were invented during the First Outbreak. The original ones were made by Catchfly, but they were no good; the disease would pass, but the person would pass away along with it. But then Beaker's brothers made some nice ones. Crowfoot's weren't too shabby, and neither were Flanky's...

6.Bachelor: ...What is the First Outbreak?

6.Bachelor: ...What is the First Outbreak?

7.Doghead: Five years ago something really creepy happened in the Crude Sprawl. People fell sick one after the other-and rapidly, too. The whole district got infected in twenty four hours, house after house. People would burst into sickness like matches burst into flames-and then, like matches, they would burn from the inside. I was a little kid back then, only six years old, but I frequented the Tower already.

7.Doghead: Five years ago something really creepy happened in the Crude Sprawl. People fell sick one after the other-and rapidly, too. The whole district got infected in twenty four hours, house after house. People would burst into sickness like matches burst into flames-and then, like matches, they would burn from the inside. I was a little kid back then, only six years old, but I frequented the Tower already.

8.Bachelor: And then what?

8.Bachelor: And then what?

9.Doghead: And then nothing. There were little to no casualties among the children-we were in the Tower when it all began. But some kids just had to get out and make themselves busy with the whole outbreak business... invent shmowders, for example. And it worked. It all went on for several days-and then sort of withered all by itself. But the shmowders stayed.

10.Bachelor: And where are they?

10.Bachelor: And where are they?

11.Doghead: Every single shmowder that we know of had been stashed away in a safe place here, so that no one would poison themselves, but here we are-no shmowders...

11.Doghead: Every single shmowder that we know of had been stashed away in a safe place here, so that no one would poison themselves, but here we are-no shmowders...

10.Bachelor: Can I speak to the inventors of shmowders?

10.Bachelor: Can I speak to the inventors of shmowders?

11.Doghead: Nope. Beaker's brothers have grown up and left. Catchfly and Crowfoot died during the tests-back then, I mean. This is why shmowders are so valuable! You can't reinvent them. You need to know the ingredients...

6.Bachelor: I'm dying to know how exactly these pharmaceutical prodigies were producing these things.

6.Bachelor: I'm dying to know how exactly these pharmaceutical prodigies were producing these things.

7.Doghead: Well, you know... fiddled here, tampered there. Sniffed around for and obtained different drugs; ground them in a mortar, then mixed them together. But you can't just go ahead an do it, it requires a certain hunch. And even if the hunch was correct, shmowders are still always massively harmful, of course... but they make the disease leave the body. You end up poisoned but alive.

8.Bachelor: What disease?

8.Bachelor: What disease?

9.Doghead: Five years ago something really creepy happened in the Crude Sprawl. People fell sick one after the other-and rapidly, too. The whole district got infected in twenty four hours, house after house. People would burst into sickness like matches burst into flames-and then, like matches, they would burn from the inside. I was a little kid back then, only six years old, but I frequented the Tower already.

2.Bachelor: What's wrong with your head?

2.Bachelor: What's wrong with your head?

3.Doghead: It's personal protective equipment! It reflects valuable thoughts back into my skull so that I don't lose them along the way. Scares people away quite nicely too. We aren't just hanging here, you know, we're on a combat mission. Well, we were-and then we totally blew it...

3.Doghead: It's personal protective equipment! It reflects valuable thoughts back into my skull so that I don't lose them along the way. Scares people away quite nicely too. We aren't just hanging here, you know, we're on a combat mission. Well, we were-and then we totally blew it...

4.Bachelor: Really? How so?

4.Bachelor: Really? How so?

5.Doghead: How are we supposed to find the shmowders now? Do we seriously need to detain every little kid in the street? What do we barter with them for? And we can't take the shmowders by force. Bullying is against the rules-Khan would totally bite our heads off for that.

5.Doghead: How are we supposed to find the shmowders now? Do we seriously need to detain every little kid in the street? What do we barter with them for? And we can't take the shmowders by force. Bullying is against the rules-Khan would totally bite our heads off for that.

6.Bachelor: 'Shmowders'? As in... 'powders'? What are you talking about?

6.Bachelor: 'Shmowders'? As in... 'powders'? What are you talking about?

7.Doghead: Oooh, powders! Powders-shmowders! Shmowders are sanative mixtures. They were invented during the First Outbreak. The original ones were made by Catchfly, but they were no good; the disease would pass, but the person would pass away along with it. But then Beaker's brothers made some nice ones. Crowfoot's weren't too shabby, and neither were Flanky's...

1.Woman: Who is it...? Is that a person...? Will you help me...?

2.Bachelor: What's wrong with you? Can't you see me?

3.Woman: So hot... It hurts! My head... is about to burst... Blood is curdling in my veins... I'd scream, but I don't want the children to hear...

4.Bachelor: There are no children here.

4.Bachelor: There are no children here.

5.Woman: I keep hearing children's voices... The girls are crying, and the boy is laughing... We mustn't scare them... Don't tell them and don't let them in here...

5.Woman: I keep hearing children's voices... The girls are crying, and the boy is laughing... We mustn't scare them... Don't tell them and don't let them in here...

6.Bachelor: You're delirious. There is no one here.

6.Bachelor: You're delirious. There is no one here.

7.Woman: Don't come close. We are dying already. I told my sisters not to go outside... So they're... shambling... around the house...

7.Woman: Don't come close. We are dying already. I told my sisters not to go outside... So they're... shambling... around the house...

8.Bachelor: All right. Hold on, I'll get help.

Bachelor & Executor

1.Executor: Everyone's dead here, see? No one knows why. Perhaps it's an echo of yesterday's vendetta... We're a bit at a loss about this loss ourselves.

1.Executor: Everyone's dead here, see? No one knows why. Perhaps it's an echo of yesterday's vendetta... We're a bit at a loss about this loss ourselves.

2.Bachelor: What am I supposed to do with the provisions?

2.Bachelor: What am I supposed to do with the provisions?

3.Executor: The dead have no use for it. Give your offerings to Lara. Wasn't it she that asked you to bring food? She wanted to call her shelter the House of the Living, didn't she?

3.Executor: The dead have no use for it. Give your offerings to Lara. Wasn't it she that asked you to bring food? She wanted to call her shelter the House of the Living, didn't she?

4.Bachelor: What, is she supposed to refashion her own home into a lazar house now?

4.Bachelor: What, is she supposed to refashion her own home into a lazar house now?

5.Executor: She won't need it anymore anyway. Lara only has a few days left. Do persuade her to make the most of them...

5.Executor: She won't need it anymore anyway. Lara only has a few days left. Do persuade her to make the most of them...

6.Bachelor: What? Is she going to die?

6.Bachelor: What? Is she going to die?

7.Executor: How should we know? We are not the ones in charge here. We only know one thing for certain-it won't take long. We have nothing to do with it.

7.Executor: How should we know? We are not the ones in charge here. We only know one thing for certain-it won't take long. We have nothing to do with it.

8.Bachelor: Who does then?

8.Bachelor: Who does then?

9.Executor: That will become very obvious very soon. Hurry, or poor Lara will die of starvation today...

9.Executor: That will become very obvious very soon. Hurry, or poor Lara will die of starvation today...

10.Bachelor: I will find a way to get to you, just you wait.

10.Bachelor: I will find a way to get to you, just you wait.

8.Bachelor: Liar!

8.Bachelor: Liar!

6.Bachelor: You have a sour sense of humour.

6.Bachelor: You have a sour sense of humour.

4.Bachelor: Yes, you're right.

4.Bachelor: Yes, you're right.

2.Bachelor: Who are you? Are you an actor from the Theatre?

2.Bachelor: Who are you? Are you an actor from the Theatre?

3.Executor: No. Do I look like an actor? I'm, like, the opposite of an actor. I've merely borrowed this outfit, you see. It covers the face and... hmm... offers some sort of protection. Moreover, it conceals the disgusting sights and gets rid of the omnipresent stench!

4.Bachelor: Sorry, what?

5.Executor: The mask has no eye openings, only these narrow slits. See? It's like I'm squinting. And there are ground grains saturated with twyrine brew in the beak. They kill microbes and get rid of the smell.

Day 3

Bachelor & Patrolman

1.Patrolman: That villain, to chop up a lad like that... He must know his trade well, eh, dressing carcasses 'n the likes... Look, over there, they're carrying the body with all the cuttings.

1.Patrolman: That villain, to chop up a lad like that... He must know his trade well, eh, dressing carcasses 'n the likes... Look, over there, they're carrying the body with all the cuttings.

2.Bachelor: Where to?

2.Bachelor: Where to?

3.Patrolman: The cemetery, where else. To prepare for burial. Why d'ya ask, sir?

3.Patrolman: The cemetery, where else. To prepare for burial. Why d'ya ask, sir?

4.Bachelor: It's you who have to report to me, volunteer, not the other way round!

4.Bachelor: It's you who have to report to me, volunteer, not the other way round!

4.Bachelor: Professional curiosity...

4.Bachelor: Professional curiosity...

4.Bachelor: Why wasn't the body returned to the family?

4.Bachelor: Why wasn't the body returned to the family?

5.Patrolman: Ain't got no family. There's only Grace to give him solace now.

5.Patrolman: Ain't got no family. There's only Grace to give him solace now.

6.Bachelor: I see.

6.Bachelor: I see.

Bachelor & Patrolman

1.Patrolman: Anything I can help you with, good sir?

1.Patrolman: Anything I can help you with, good sir?

2.Bachelor: Was this body brought from an infected district?

2.Bachelor: Was this body brought from an infected district?

3.Patrolman: Yes. We're preparing it for the burial. What's in it for you?

3.Patrolman: Yes. We're preparing it for the burial. What's in it for you?

4.Bachelor: I need it for my work.

4.Bachelor: I need it for my work.

5.Patrolman: Ain't that right... Well, doctor's work is vital work all right. It's not like you're body-snatching for fun, right? You're working in the interests of the public!

5.Patrolman: Ain't that right... Well, doctor's work is vital work all right. It's not like you're body-snatching for fun, right? You're working in the interests of the public!

6.Bachelor: Spot on.

6.Bachelor: Spot on.

7.Patrolman: Ten thousand money-and it's yours.

7.Patrolman: Ten thousand money-and it's yours.

8.Bachelor: Are you out of your mind?

8.Bachelor: Are you out of your mind?

9.Patrolman: I'm not gonna offer twice.

9.Patrolman: I'm not gonna offer twice.

10.Bachelor: All right. Here it is.

10.Bachelor: All right. Here it is.

10.Bachelor: You will give it to me since that is my order. By the name of governor Saburov!

10.Bachelor: You will give it to me since that is my order. By the name of governor Saburov!

11.Patrolman: Governor Saburov? Governor Saburov is not my commanding officer! I'm a volunteer-do you get that, doctor? Or do I need to spell it out for you?

11.Patrolman: Governor Saburov? Governor Saburov is not my commanding officer! I'm a volunteer-do you get that, doctor? Or do I need to spell it out for you?

12.Bachelor: Perhaps we could strike a bargain?

12.Bachelor: Silence! Know your place!

12.Bachelor: Silence! Know your place!

8.Bachelor: Deal.

8.Bachelor: Deal.

4.Bachelor: No questions! Did governor Saburov forget to inform you of my mandate?

4.Bachelor: No questions! Did governor Saburov forget to inform you of my mandate?

6.Bachelor: Perhaps we could strike a bargain?

2.Bachelor: It's fine. I'm just picking the perfect spot for my grave.

Bachelor & Patrolman

1.Patrolman: Don't worry, sir, the evil-doers are dead.

1.Patrolman: Don't worry, sir, the evil-doers are dead.

2.Bachelor: Upon Olgimsky's orders?

2.Bachelor: Upon Olgimsky's orders?

3.Patrolman: Armed resistance. They must have thought Fat Vlad had sent us. But there's something fishy about this 'ere business!

3.Patrolman: Armed resistance. They must have thought Fat Vlad had sent us. But there's something fishy about this 'ere business!

4.Bachelor: Why?

4.Bachelor: Why?

5.Patrolman: It gets worse. That beast carved 'im up and wrapped 'im up. Prepared 'im for something. Been waiting for the Ripper! He's still at large, is 'im that's killed old Burakh. Ain't gone nowhere; ain't fooling anyone! It was for 'im the butcher did it, no question about it...

5.Patrolman: It gets worse. That beast carved 'im up and wrapped 'im up. Prepared 'im for something. Been waiting for the Ripper! He's still at large, is 'im that's killed old Burakh. Ain't gone nowhere; ain't fooling anyone! It was for 'im the butcher did it, no question about it...

6.Bachelor: What in the world makes you think so?

6.Bachelor: What in the world makes you think so?

7.Patrolman: He was waiting for 'im, so he was... Anyway, it's all pointing towards it. Good thing we were there to dissuade 'im. But in a different neighbourhood, another butcher like that slipped away! I just got the report! How I'd love to give the beast a good thrashing! 'im and whoever's paying 'im! Shame I can't leave my post...

7.Patrolman: He was waiting for 'im, so he was... Anyway, it's all pointing towards it. Good thing we were there to dissuade 'im. But in a different neighbourhood, another butcher like that slipped away! I just got the report! How I'd love to give the beast a good thrashing! 'im and whoever's paying 'im! Shame I can't leave my post...

8.Bachelor: I'd rather you not go to extremes like that next time.

8.Bachelor: I'd rather you not go to extremes like that next time.

8.Bachelor: And what happened to the body?

8.Bachelor: And what happened to the body?

9.Patrolman: The body was given to the family. They'll bury it.

9.Patrolman: The body was given to the family. They'll bury it.

10.Bachelor: Sounds like the right thing to do.

10.Bachelor: Sounds like the right thing to do.

6.Bachelor: Good fellows. Thank you for your service!

6.Bachelor: Good fellows. Thank you for your service!

2.Bachelor: Who were they?

2.Bachelor: Who were they?

3.Patrolman: Butchers.

3.Patrolman: Butchers.

4.Bachelor: Why did you kill them?

4.Bachelor: Why did you kill them?

5.Patrolman: For abominable sacrilege.

5.Patrolman: For abominable sacrilege.

6.Bachelor: Aren't butchers allowed to dissect bodies?

6.Bachelor: Aren't butchers allowed to dissect bodies?

7.Patrolman: Bull carcasses, yes. That's kinda self-explanatory, no, good sir? Since when are they allowed to cut people's bodies for entertainment, though? Or do they know the lines?

7.Patrolman: Bull carcasses, yes. That's kinda self-explanatory, no, good sir? Since when are they allowed to cut people's bodies for entertainment, though? Or do they know the lines?

8.Bachelor: Whose entertainment? Their own?

8.Bachelor: Whose entertainment? Their own?

9.Patrolman: It gets worse. That beast carved 'im up and wrapped 'im up. Prepared 'im for something. Been waiting for the Ripper! He's still at large, is 'im that's killed old Burakh. Ain't gone nowhere; ain't fooling anyone! It was for 'im the butcher did it, no question about it...

9.Patrolman: It gets worse. That beast carved 'im up and wrapped 'im up. Prepared 'im for something. Been waiting for the Ripper! He's still at large, is 'im that's killed old Burakh. Ain't gone nowhere; ain't fooling anyone! It was for 'im the butcher did it, no question about it...

10.Bachelor: What in the world makes you think so?

10.Bachelor: What in the world makes you think so?

11.Patrolman: He was waiting for 'im, so he was... Anyway, it's all pointing towards it. Good thing we were there to dissuade 'im. But in a different neighbourhood, another butcher like that slipped away! I just got the report! How I'd love to give the beast a good thrashing! 'im and whoever's paying 'im! Shame I can't leave my post...

11.Patrolman: He was waiting for 'im, so he was... Anyway, it's all pointing towards it. Good thing we were there to dissuade 'im. But in a different neighbourhood, another butcher like that slipped away! I just got the report! How I'd love to give the beast a good thrashing! 'im and whoever's paying 'im! Shame I can't leave my post...

12.Bachelor: I'd rather you not go to extremes like that next time.

12.Bachelor: I'd rather you not go to extremes like that next time.

12.Bachelor: And what happened to the body?

12.Bachelor: And what happened to the body?

13.Patrolman: The body was given to the family. They'll bury it.

13.Patrolman: The body was given to the family. They'll bury it.

14.Bachelor: Sounds like the right thing to do.

14.Bachelor: Sounds like the right thing to do.

10.Bachelor: Good fellows. Thank you for your service!

2.Bachelor: I'm a friend of the Kains. I've come to see Khan.

3.Doghead: You're in luck then. Khan has left the Facets to mourn his grandfather. Come in-but don't try to get inside. You really don't want us all to perish, do you?

2.Bachelor: Do you think this is funny?

4.Bachelor: What are you doing here?

5.Tot: Nothing! I meant well. I won't do it again.

6.Bachelor: Are you testing a powd-erm, shmowder? Tell me the truth!

7.Tot: No. I mean yes. I'm a brave boy, aren't I?

7.Tot: No. I mean yes. I'm a brave boy, aren't I?

8.Bachelor: Let me check if you have a fever. Are you sick yet?

8.Bachelor: Let me check if you have a fever. Are you sick yet?

9.Tot: I don't know. Doesn't look like it. I've been waiting all this time to fall sick so I could do the test. Nothing so far. Bad luck.

9.Tot: I don't know. Doesn't look like it. I've been waiting all this time to fall sick so I could do the test. Nothing so far. Bad luck.

10.Bachelor: Ha! 'Bad luck'... Are you completely mental?

10.Bachelor: Ha! 'Bad luck'... Are you completely mental?

11.Tot: I've been told that this is the place where this, y'know, sort of tongue comes out of the ground, a tongue made of dirty lumps. Like made of thick air... You're standing at that exact spot, sir.

11.Tot: I've been told that this is the place where this, y'know, sort of tongue comes out of the ground, a tongue made of dirty lumps. Like made of thick air... You're standing at that exact spot, sir.

12.Bachelor: You nitwit! Spare the rod and spoil the child.

Day 4

Bachelor & Executor

1.Executor: The theatre is closed by supreme command! The season's over. The troupe's disbanded. Follow the news on the poster columns.

1.Executor: The theatre is closed by supreme command! The season's over. The troupe's disbanded. Follow the news on the poster columns.

2.Bachelor: Who ordered the Theatre closed?

2.Bachelor: Who ordered the Theatre closed?

3.Executor: Vlad Olgimsky, better known as Vlad the Voluminous.

3.Executor: Vlad Olgimsky, better known as Vlad the Voluminous.

4.Bachelor: Olgimsky... I've actually come to relay his orders to you. From now on all you theatre folk are placed under my command. You will do whatever I tell you to.

4.Bachelor: Olgimsky... I've actually come to relay his orders to you. From now on all you theatre folk are placed under my command. You will do whatever I tell you to.

5.Executor: Oooh... thrrrilling! We theatre folk thought it was, well, the other way around-that it was you who had recently been placed under our command and would do whatever we... ahem... well, it's not really done through talking...

5.Executor: Oooh... thrrrilling! We theatre folk thought it was, well, the other way around-that it was you who had recently been placed under our command and would do whatever we... ahem... well, it's not really done through talking...

6.Bachelor: Don't try your luck, beakhead.

6.Bachelor: Don't try your luck, beakhead.

7.Executor: Unfortunately, our most esteemed and graceful sir stage assistant has gone home with the keys. May it be known to you that he lives in the Chine district. As soon as it became known that a calamity is unfolding in the Chine, a tragedian went there, but we haven't heard from him since.

7.Executor: Unfortunately, our most esteemed and graceful sir stage assistant has gone home with the keys. May it be known to you that he lives in the Chine district. As soon as it became known that a calamity is unfolding in the Chine, a tragedian went there, but we haven't heard from him since.

8.Bachelor: I'll find him.

8.Bachelor: I'll find him.

8.Bachelor: If I find out you lied to me, I'll have you hanged.

8.Bachelor: If I find out you lied to me, I'll have you hanged.

3.Executor: It doesn't meet the health regulations. Yesterday some people tried to turn it into a conference chamber-use it to invite elected representatives from the common people to cooperate on the plague issue.

3.Executor: It doesn't meet the health regulations. Yesterday some people tried to turn it into a conference chamber-use it to invite elected representatives from the common people to cooperate on the plague issue.

10.Bachelor: If I find out you lied to me, I'll have you hanged.

6.Bachelor: Open the building. I intend to make some changes inside.

6.Bachelor: Open the building. I intend to make some changes inside.

7.Executor: Unfortunately, our most esteemed and graceful sir stage assistant has gone home with the keys. May it be known to you that he lives in the Chine district. As soon as it became known that a calamity is unfolding in the Chine, a tragedian went there, but we haven't heard from him since.

2.Bachelor: You are exactly who I'm looking for.

3.Tragedian: Then please be so kind as to tell me what I can do for you.

4.Bachelor: Twyrine?

Sometimes there's no effect at all. But, well, it's not so well-loved for its effect; those helpful properties were only discovered after the plague broke out...

6.Bachelor: Thank you.

6.Bachelor: Find a better use for it.

2.Bachelor: I don't need anything.

Day 5

Bachelor & Patrolman

1.Patrolman: No trespassing.

1.Patrolman: No trespassing.

2.Bachelor: I'm not a trespasser-just a passer-by. What about you? Are you, by any chance, the infamous dangerous offender?

2.Bachelor: I'm not a trespasser-just a passer-by. What about you? Are you, by any chance, the infamous dangerous offender?

3.Patrolman: What's in it for you?

3.Patrolman: What's in it for you?

4.Bachelor: I command you to set him free.

4.Bachelor: I command you to set him free.

5.Patrolman: I was strictly ordered by governor Saburov to guard the prisoner with my life. There was a special order too: if the prisoner dies of the Sand Pest, we ain't supposed to bury him or give the body to the undertakers. We're to inform the governor in person and await further instructions.

5.Patrolman: I was strictly ordered by governor Saburov to guard the prisoner with my life. There was a special order too: if the prisoner dies of the Sand Pest, we ain't supposed to bury him or give the body to the undertakers. We're to inform the governor in person and await further instructions.

6.Bachelor: Don't you think that's a bit too strict?

6.Bachelor: Don't you think that's a bit too strict?

7.Patrolman: Strict my ass! We put almost seventy people behind bars yesterday, on suspicion, of course. Killed loads of folks too. Must've been thugs and cutthroats, the ones we've killed. I've heard their thug friends are all up in arms, planning to take revenge on us... But they're out of men-and out of luck.

We're to inform the governor in person and await further instructions.

Bachelor & Young Man

1.Young Man: You've made a wise choice, Bachelor. But we've encountered certain complications...

1.Young Man: You've made a wise choice, Bachelor. But we've encountered certain complications...

2.Bachelor: What is it?

2.Bachelor: What is it?

3.Young Man: There are already half a thousand people who have agreed to leave the infected districts for the Cathedral. It's you who they owe their lives to, Bachelor.

3.Young Man: There are already half a thousand people who have agreed to leave the infected districts for the Cathedral. It's you who they owe their lives to, Bachelor.

4.Bachelor: You've mentioned complications.

4.Bachelor: You've mentioned complications.

5.Young Man: There are food issues. We still have enough water, but the people are starving. The crowd is beginning to get cranky. They demand to be allowed to go search for food in the clean districts.

5.Young Man: There are food issues. We still have enough water, but the people are starving. The crowd is beginning to get cranky. They demand to be allowed to go search for food in the clean districts.

6.Bachelor: And I demand they don't. Don't let anyone out. Direct orders from me.

6.Bachelor: I'll speak to Olgimsky. You will be getting food supplies.

8.Bachelor: I. I'm almost done with the vaccine.

Bachelor & Young Man

1.Young Man: Bachelor Dankovsky! I'm not sure what your instructions were and what Big Vlad's opinion on this is, but we've only received a tiny fraction of the food supply required. People demand that we let couriers in.

2.Bachelor: I know the town is starving. They know it as well. The goods train is going to arrive very soon. They'll have to be patient.

Bachelor & Tragedian

1.Tragedian: Spare some change for a poor miserable actor! Give him food. Yours truly would gladly gobble down anything-even a piece of infected meat from the forbidden storage. I'm so desperate to live just a couple more days to witness the ending!

1.Tragedian: Spare some change for a poor miserable actor! Give him food. Yours truly would gladly gobble down anything-even a piece of infected meat from the forbidden storage. I'm so desperate to live just a couple more days to witness the ending!

2.Bachelor: And the miserable actor is you?

2.Bachelor: And the miserable actor is you?

3.Tragedian: That's my persona, 'a miserable actor'. Although, in all honesty, there are no happy Masks in The Fatal Loss-and I'll have you know that it's a classical mime play that's been on the stage of our Theatre for several generations. It only has bold Masks, just Masks, and miserable Masks...

3.Tragedian: That's my persona, 'a miserable actor'. Although, in all honesty, there are no happy Masks in The Fatal Loss-and I'll have you know that it's a classical mime play that's been on the stage of our Theatre for several generations. It only has bold Masks, just Masks, and miserable Masks...

4.Bachelor: What is the play about?

4.Bachelor: What is the play about?

5.Tragedian: The Loss... or rather The Fatal Loss-'fatal' is important here, but not because it has to do with death, but rather because the loss was bound to happen; it's about inevitability... Where was I? Ah yes! This tragedy is a mime performance that's become somewhat of a ritual for us. It's the only play we stage. The author remains unknown, although legend has it that they were of divine nature...

5.Tragedian: The Loss... or rather The Fatal Loss-'fatal' is important here, but not because it has to do with death, but rather because the loss was bound to happen; it's about inevitability... Where was I? Ah yes! This tragedy is a mime performance that's become somewhat of a ritual for us. It's the only play we stage. The author remains unknown, although legend has it that they were of divine nature...

6.Bachelor: You only stage one play? Don't you get fed up with it?

6.Bachelor: You only stage one play? Don't you get fed up with it?

7.Tragedian: It has its merits. Firstly, the story is true. Secondly, it adds a precious hint of sacred service to the performance. Throughout all the years The Loss has been on stage, it's been accompanied by a chain of mysterious coincidences. One might suggest that the structure of this ancient drama emulates the structure of the Universe.

7.Tragedian: It has its merits. Firstly, the story is true. Secondly, it adds a precious hint of sacred service to the performance. Throughout all the years The Loss has been on stage, it's been accompanied by a chain of mysterious coincidences. One might suggest that the structure of this ancient drama emulates the structure of the Universe.

8.Bachelor: So what's the story?

8.Bachelor: So what's the story?

9.Tragedian: The story's all around you, Bachelor! Just look how tragic the tragedy that's unfolding in the town is! That's just additional proof to the truthfulness of our esteemed impresario's words: a play is performed onstage-but it's executed in real life...

9.Tragedian: The story's all around you, Bachelor! Just look how tragic the tragedy that's unfolding in the town is! That's just additional proof to the truthfulness of our esteemed impresario's words: a play is performed onstage-but it's executed in real life...

10.Bachelor: Fine. I'll talk to Immortell about it.

8.Bachelor: Yeah, sure.

5.Tragedian: You are mistaken. That's not a beak, but rather a talon. No, Bachelor; you've seen the Miserable Mask and the Just Mask-that is to say, the punishing one. The Bold Mask is you.

2.Bachelor: Why are you begging?

2.Bachelor: Why are you begging?

3.Tragedian: We've been thrown out of the Theatre. The Fatal Loss is now performed right on the streets. But our impresario is convinced that it's for the best-after all, The Fatal Loss is as tragic a play as it gets. Just see the sick people dancing; hear the squirming of those whose mouths have been sewn shut! They make for perfect extras!

3.Tragedian: We've been thrown out of the Theatre. The Fatal Loss is now performed right on the streets. But our impresario is convinced that it's for the best-after all, The Fatal Loss is as tragic a play as it gets. Just see the sick people dancing; hear the squirming of those whose mouths have been sewn shut! They make for perfect extras!

4.Bachelor: Seems like your troupe is about to become very wealthy very soon.

4.Bachelor: Seems like your troupe is about to become very wealthy very soon.

5.Tragedian: The audience is enourmous, but, alas, very few of its members are actually financially reliable. Their pockets may be stuffed with coins, but their arms are twisted by the heartless fever that won't let them give away their property.

5.Tragedian: The audience is enourmous, but, alas, very few of its members are actually financially reliable. Their pockets may be stuffed with coins, but their arms are twisted by the heartless fever that won't let them give away their property.

6.Bachelor: Keep your chin up.

6.Bachelor: Keep your chin up.

4.Bachelor: Keep on performing then.

4.Bachelor: Keep on performing then.

5.Tragedian: You've got the leading part, don't you forget that! Although your talkativeness makes you a rather lousy mime.

5.Tragedian: You've got the leading part, don't you forget that! Although your talkativeness makes you a rather lousy mime.

6.Bachelor: Hopefully I don't ruin the whole thing.

6.Bachelor: Hopefully I don't ruin the whole thing.

6.Bachelor: Prompt me my lines then please?

6.Bachelor: Prompt me my lines then please?

2.Bachelor: God will provide.

2.Bachelor: God will provide.

Bachelor & Willow

1.Willow: Why are you giving me that look?

1.Willow: Why are you giving me that look?

2.Bachelor: Is Var the Hunchback your father?

2.Bachelor: Is Var the Hunchback your father?

3.Willow: Did he send you?

3.Willow: Did he send you?

4.Bachelor: Yes. He's worried about you. Come with me. The streets are unsafe, but I'll make sure that you get home in one piece.

4.Bachelor: Yes. He's worried about you. Come with me. The streets are unsafe, but I'll make sure that you get home in one piece.

5.Willow: But I don't want to go! I'd rather stay here. My stepfather is a burdensome custodian-and I've had enough of it.

5.Willow: But I don't want to go! I'd rather stay here. My stepfather is a burdensome custodian-and I've had enough of it.

6.Bachelor: Don't you love him?

6.Bachelor: Don't you love him?

7.Willow: That's a very complicated question. When I was a child, he kidnapped me from my real father, and when my father came to rescue me from the Caravan, Var killed him. He did it because he loved me. I only found out about it yesterday. So what am I supposed to feel?

7.Willow: That's a very complicated question. When I was a child, he kidnapped me from my real father, and when my father came to rescue me from the Caravan, Var killed him. He did it because he loved me. I only found out about it yesterday. So what am I supposed to feel?

8.Bachelor: All right. I'll just let him know of your whereabouts then.

8.Bachelor: All right. I'll just let him know of your whereabouts then.

9.Willow: No, please! Don't do that. He has no idea where I spend my nights! If he ever gets even the slightest hint of suspicion of how I choose to spend my leisure time, he'll tear both the owners and the patrons of this lovely establishment to pieces... But that's all right, I will speak to him. Personally. I'll tell him I've had enough.

9.Willow: No, please! Don't do that. He has no idea where I spend my nights! If he ever gets even the slightest hint of suspicion of how I choose to spend my leisure time, he'll tear both the owners and the patrons of this lovely establishment to pieces... But that's all right, I will speak to him. Personally. I'll tell him I've had enough.

10.Bachelor: What do you mean, you've had enough?

10.Bachelor: What do you mean, you've had enough?

11.Willow: These are the last days of my life, and I intend to spend them like I want to. That is to say, here. But I'll be the person to tell him that; I'll be waiting for you at nine o'clock in the Blind Backyard. We'll go see him together. Will you stand up for me if he resorts to physical violence?

11.Willow: These are the last days of my life, and I intend to spend them like I want to. That is to say, here. But I'll be the person to tell him that; I'll be waiting for you at nine o'clock in the Blind Backyard. We'll go see him together. Will you stand up for me if he resorts to physical violence?

12.Bachelor: Why not go right now?

12.Bachelor: Why not go right now?

13.Willow: There is still something I have to do here. We'll meet at nine o'clock, when it's dark. I'd ask you to pick me up, but that would be impossible. I can't be seen picked up by a man.

13.Willow: There is still something I have to do here. We'll meet at nine o'clock, when it's dark. I'd ask you to pick me up, but that would be impossible. I can't be seen picked up by a man.

14.Bachelor: Just be careful.

14.Bachelor: Just be careful.

12.Bachelor: I will.

12.Bachelor: I will.

12.Bachelor: Just tell me where the Blind Backyard is.
